statement.text: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vEDS, formerly EDS Type IV) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by COL3A1 mutations affecting type III collagen synthesis. It is the most severe form of EDS, characterized by arterial, intestinal, and uterine fragility with high risk of spontaneous rupture. Median survival is 50 years, with major complications occurring by age 40 in most patients.
statement.formal: vEDS: AD, COL3A1 mutation; Arterial/visceral/uterine rupture; Thin translucent skin, acrogeria; Most lethal EDS type, median survival ~50 years

explanation.intuition: Type III collagen is the main structural protein in blood vessel walls and hollow organs. In vEDS, this collagen is defective - imagine building a pressurized pipe with substandard materials. The vessels look normal but can rupture spontaneously without warning, even at normal blood pressures. Unlike Marfan where vessels dilate before rupture, vEDS vessels can rupture without prior aneurysm formation.
explanation.key_insight: Surgery in vEDS is extremely hazardous due to tissue fragility - tissues tear during handling, sutures pull through, and healing is impaired. Conservative management is preferred whenever possible. When surgery is unavoidable, meticulous technique with pledgets and buttressing is essential.
explanation.technical_details: COL3A1 mutations result in abnormal type III procollagen that interferes with normal collagen fibril formation (dominant negative effect). Diagnosis requires genetic testing (COL3A1 mutation) or characteristic biochemical abnormalities (abnormal type III collagen ratio on skin biopsy fibroblast culture). Major arterial complications affect medium-sized arteries: iliac, splenic, renal arteries more than aorta.

major_criteria: Family history of vEDS with documented COL3A1 mutation
Spontaneous sigmoid colon perforation without diverticular disease
minor_criteria: Characteristic facial features (thin nose and lips, sunken cheeks, small chin, prominent eyes)
Thin, translucent skin with visible veins

vascular_complications.arterial_rupture: Spontaneous, without prior aneurysm; iliac, splenic, renal arteries common
vascular_complications.aneurysm: Less common than Marfan; when present, medium-sized vessels

surgical_considerations.tissue_quality: Extremely fragile - sutures pull through, tissues tear
surgical_considerations.surgical_approach: Conservative when possible; damage control if surgery required
surgical_considerations.technique: Pledgeted sutures, avoid tension, buttress anastomoses
surgical_considerations.endovascular: May be preferred for arterial emergencies, though vessel fragility remains concern

definition.@value: Autosomal dominant disorder due to COL3A1 mutations causing type III collagen deficiency with arterial, intestinal, and uterine fragility

clinical_pearls: vEDS vessels rupture WITHOUT prior aneurysm formation - unlike Marfan/LDS
Surgery is extremely hazardous - conservative management preferred
Celiprolol may reduce arterial events (one RCT)
Spontaneous sigmoid perforation in young person = think vEDS
Pregnancy carries very high maternal mortality risk
